Award.AwardTitle: Site-Specific Time-Resolved Multidimensional Spectroscopy of Electron Transfer Dynamics
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure and Dynamics Program A of the Chemistry Division, Professor Kevin Kubarych of the University of Michigan and his graduate students are developing de novo ("from scratch") proteins to study the fundamental motion of electrons. Electron transfer processes are essential to life, and they underlie many of the most pressing challenges in developing new methods to harvest energy and convert it into useful forms. The project promotes research opportunities arising from spectroscopic tools such as used in the research via a series of workshops and meetings.

Professor Kubarych's research group uses advanced ultrafast laser spectroscopy methods to visualize electron transfer in real time using designed de novo metalloenzyme scaffolds. The combined synthetic and spectroscopic approach offers the flexibility to change the location of the electron donor and acceptor, and to add accelerating bridging side chains. Complementing this macromolecular design strategy is a spectroscopic toolset based on multidimensional spectroscopy that has been developed in the Kubarych lab. The project also uses a collaborative NSF-funded facility, the Laboratory for Ultrafast Multidimensional Optical Spectroscopy (LUMOS). LUMOS is being developed to track electron transfer and other phototriggered reactions from femtoseconds to seconds at wavelengths ranging from the UV and visible to the infrared. This extremely broad temporal and frequency range is essential to monitor changes in structure and dynamics as the charge moves through the engineered protein.

Institution.Name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

POR.DRECONTENT:
Achieving a detailed understanding of the fundamental steps that occur during natural and synthetic chemical reactions requires advanced measurement techniques. Using laser based spectroscopy, this project used stroboscopic snapshots of some of the fastest processes in chemistry. By engineering entirely artificial enzymes (proteins that accelerate chemical transformations) as well as employing simpler model systems, this research project advanced knowledge of how the context influences chemistry in systems ranging from complex interfaces to designer catalysts. In living organisms as well as in research laboratories and industrial plants, most chemistry takes place in a liquid environment. Life on Earth exists in a water environment, but there are hundreds of other liquids with vastly different properties that are essential for modern chemistry. This project examined how water behaves when it is next to large components that are ubiquitous in living organisms. Since water can act either to promote or to prohibit key chemical processes, such as the movement and transfer of energy and charges (like electrons and protons), the role water plays is actually just as important as that played by the main “actors.” This project found that in some instances, the motion of water is significantly slowed in the presence of the biological components, and other times, especially for those known to be “biocompatible,” the water behaves essentially the same as it does as a pure liquid. This finding opens the idea that biocompatibility—a key aspect of medical products such as drugs and prosthetics—may require that the water be allowed to move dynamically as if the foreign object were not there. 

 

One way to learn what is special about chemistry in water is to study what happens in other liquids, as well as in mixtures (or “solutions”) of other liquids. Using an engineered biomimic that can accelerate (i.e. “catalyze”) the generation of hydrogen, this project applied laser spectroscopy to capture the very fast motion of a so-called “dendrimeric” catalyst. This catalyst uses only inexpensive and abundant iron, as opposed to the much rarer and more expensive metals such as platinum, grafted to a dendrimer, which is a molecule that resembles the shape made by the veins in leaves. By altering the liquid among several common solvents, the spectroscopic measurements illustrate how the catalyst motion and that of the liquid changes due to the differences in the interactions between the liquid and the catalyst. These findings can be correlated with the performance of the catalyst in order to optimize both the reaction conditions and the design of next-generation hydrogen producing catalyst, which are going to be central to the establishment of a carbon-free, hydrogen-based energy infrastructure. 

 


Last Modified: 01/05/2020
Modified by: Kevin J Kubarych
